guide.introduction:
How would you like to talk over a laser beam? In about 15 minutes you can set up your own laser communication system using a cheap laser pointer and a few parts from RadioShack. The audio signal from a microphone varies the power feeding the laser, so that its brightness changes, following the shape of the original sound wave. At the receiving end, a solar cell or photo-resistor converts the oscillating light signal back into the original sound.

The communication is completely private, with no wire connection to tap into. Only you will be able hear what comes over the secret laser link.

Check out more Weekend Projects.

Relevant parts
  • Laser pointer
  • Batteries
  • Wire
  • Transformer, audio output, 1kΩ primary coil, 8Ω secondary
  • Battery holder, 3 x AAA
  • Alligator clip leads (2-10) with points fine enough to connect to the inside of the laser pointer
  • LED, 2-lead bicolor
  • Wire, hookup, 22 gauge stranded
  • Amplifier, mini, portable
  • Microphone, with cable and plug
  • Crystal earphone
  • Battery, 9V
  • Snap connector for 9V battery
  • Photoresistor, cadmium sulfide (CdS)
  • Resistor, 220Ω
Tools
  • Audio plug, 1/8", mono
  • Helping Hands tool
  • Radio, transistor
  • Solder, lead-free
  • Soldering Iron, 15-Watt

lines.text: It is recommend that you solder this project, but initially, it’s easier to make it and test it out using alligator clip leads.
lines.text_raw: It is recommend that you solder this project, but initially, it’s easier to make it and test it out using alligator clip leads.

lines.text: Remove the batteries from the laser. Connect the external battery pack to the laser’s power contacts with 2 alligator clips. Usually you’ll connect one lead to the battery case and the other to the spring inside.
lines.text_raw: Remove the batteries from the laser. Connect the external battery pack to the laser’s power contacts with 2 alligator clips. Usually you’ll connect one lead to the battery case and the other to the spring inside.

lines.text: Some laser pointers are easy to disassemble; you can remove the circuit board and see the power contacts conveniently marked with a plus and a minus. If it doesn’t light, try reversing the power;  this won’t harm the laser.
lines.text_raw: Some laser pointers are easy to disassemble; you can remove the circuit board and see the power contacts conveniently marked with a plus and a minus. If it doesn’t light, try reversing the power;  this won’t harm the laser.

lines.text: Figure out how to hold the laser’s button down with a rubber band, wire, or tape.
lines.text_raw: Figure out how to hold the laser’s button down with a rubber band, wire, or tape.

lines.text: Remove the batteries. Following the schematic, connect the bicolor LED across the 1,000-ohm (1kΩ) side of the transformer. With the transformer shown here, this means connecting it to the green and blue wires. We don’t need the tap wire (the black wire in between).
lines.text_raw: Remove the batteries. Following the schematic, connect the bicolor LED across the 1,000-ohm (1kΩ) side of the transformer. With the transformer shown here, this means connecting it to the green and blue wires. We don’t need the tap wire (the black wire in between).

lines.text: The LED protects the laser from high voltage spikes, since so many cheap lasers nowadays have no onboard protection circuit. If you see the LED flash, that indicates a spike.
lines.text_raw: The LED protects the laser from high voltage spikes, since so many cheap lasers nowadays have no onboard protection circuit. If you see the LED flash, that indicates a spike.

lines.text: Since we're using a bicolor LED, we don't have to worry about polarity and can connect it either way.
lines.text_raw: Since we're using a bicolor LED, we don't have to worry about polarity and can connect it either way.

lines.text: Connect the same two transformer leads in-line between the battery pack and the laser.
lines.text_raw: Connect the same two transformer leads in-line between the battery pack and the laser.

lines.text: Connect two leads to the earphone plug. Unscrew the cover, solder leads to the plug terminals, and replace the cover.
lines.text_raw: Connect two leads to the earphone plug. Unscrew the cover, solder leads to the plug terminals, and replace the cover.

lines.text: Connect the earphone plug to the 8Ω side of the transformer using alligator clips.
lines.text_raw: Connect the earphone plug to the 8Ω side of the transformer using alligator clips.

lines.text: That’s it! We have a laser transmitter, in just a few minutes!
lines.text_raw: That’s it! We have a laser transmitter, in just a few minutes!

lines.text: Plug the headphone plug into a transistor radio, which will be our signal source for testing.
lines.text_raw: Plug the headphone plug into a transistor radio, which will be our signal source for testing.

lines.text: For the receiver, connect a 9V battery across a cadmium sulfide (CdS) photoresistor and an earphone, so that battery, earphone, and photoresistor are all parallel.
lines.text_raw: For the receiver, connect a 9V battery across a cadmium sulfide (CdS) photoresistor and an earphone, so that battery, earphone, and photoresistor are all parallel.

lines.text: The photocell changes its resistance proportional to the amount of light hitting it. Paired with a battery, this acts like a solar cell.
lines.text_raw: The photocell changes its resistance proportional to the amount of light hitting it. Paired with a battery, this acts like a solar cell.

lines.text: Add a 220Ω resistor in series with the battery to reduce power consumption and prevent heating of the photoresistor.
lines.text_raw: Add a 220Ω resistor in series with the battery to reduce power consumption and prevent heating of the photoresistor.

lines.text: We’ll test the system by transmitting a radio signal and amplifying the receiver so we can hear it across the room. First, replace the earphone of your receiver with an audio plug (or just clip the audio plug to  the earphone wires), and plug it into an amp or stereo. Here we use a mini portable amplifier.
lines.text_raw: We’ll test the system by transmitting a radio signal and amplifying the receiver so we can hear it across the room. First, replace the earphone of your receiver with an audio plug (or just clip the audio plug to  the earphone wires), and plug it into an amp or stereo. Here we use a mini portable amplifier.

lines.text: With the radio off, plug in the transmitter. Turn up the volume on the amplifier until you hear a hiss, then turn it down until it isn’t noticeable.
lines.text_raw: With the radio off, plug in the transmitter. Turn up the volume on the amplifier until you hear a hiss, then turn it down until it isn’t noticeable.

lines.text: With the lights low, aim the laser across the room so it hits the solar cell or photoresistor. You may hear some clicks or pops. Now turn on the radio and adjust its volume until you hear it across the room.
lines.text_raw: With the lights low, aim the laser across the room so it hits the solar cell or photoresistor. You may hear some clicks or pops. Now turn on the radio and adjust its volume until you hear it across the room.

lines.text: If you don’t hear it, try increasing the amp’s volume before you turn up the radio. If you pull out the earphone plug, the radio should be just audible.
lines.text_raw: If you don’t hear it, try increasing the amp’s volume before you turn up the radio. If you pull out the earphone plug, the radio should be just audible.

lines.text: Depending on your signal source, you also might want to reverse the transformer. Some devices,  like iPods, don’t have enough power to drive 8Ω speakers, so you should connect them across the 1kΩ side. This arrangement will dim the laser, but won’t affect its range much.
lines.text_raw: Depending on your signal source, you also might want to reverse the transformer. Some devices,  like iPods, don’t have enough power to drive 8Ω speakers, so you should connect them across the 1kΩ side. This arrangement will dim the laser, but won’t affect its range much.

lines.text: When you can hear the radio, break the laser beam with your hand, and notice that the music stops. Try chopping up the audio with your fingers.

steps.title: Your laser com system is ready!

lines.text: To send secret voice  communications, move the amp from the receiver to the transmitter and plug in a mic. You’re ready for the field; just be careful with the volume, to protect the laser.
